name: The Forest Hiker
summary: Explore the largest mangrove forest on earth – Sundarbans
description: The Sundarbans is the largest contiguous block of mangrove forest in the world. It is a playground of heavenly beauty bestowed by nature. In Bangladesh tourism, Sundarbans play the most vital role. A large number of foreigners come to Bangladesh every year only to visit this unique mangrove forest. Beside, local tourist also goes to visit Sundarbans every year. It is located on the south-west part along the Bay of Bengal of Bangladesh. The Sundarbans is the single mangrove forest in the world. The area of Sundarbans is approximately 6017 sq. km. The exciting events in the Sundarbans tour are hiking in the deep forest, country boat cruising, bird watching, night safari and campfires and also staying on vessel at wild jungle atmosphere which will definitely add to your adventure experience.

name: The Island Explorer
summary: Exploring the St. Martin which known as 'Coconut Island' and the only coral reef island in Bangladesh.
description: Saint Martin is one of the few coral islands in the world. Saint martin island in Bangladesh is called the blue heaven. Find the best hotels in st. martin & complete tour packages. Surrounding blue water, the island is way more gorgeous than you can imagine. Besides, get a touch of Cox’s Bazar sea beach.

name: The Nature Seeker |
summary: Sajek valley known as the Queen of Hills & Roof of Rangamati.
description: Sajek valley is located among a range of mountains to the southern part of Bangladesh. Although the height of the mountain range is nothing remarkable, it’s a beautiful place to visit and one of the most popular tourist destinations in Bangladesh.

name: The Peak Lover
summary: Keokradong is the former highest peak of Bangladesh with an elevation of 986 meters.
description: Keokradong is located in Bandarban and one of the top tourist spots in Bangladesh.If you get to the top of Keokradong, the hill clouds will shake you with the charming attraction. Keokadong’s peak seems to smoky from the distance. It is covered with a white cloud. Due to the deep wind, sometimes it is tough to stand on the hilltop. Rain, wind, and clouds have no time to come to the side of the Keokradong.

name: The Park Camper
summary: Ratargul Swamp Forest is a fresh water marshland forest with breath taking naturual beauty
description: Ratargul Swamp Forest located close to river Goain, in Gowainghat Upazila of Sylhet District. This forest is engulfed with freshwater in most of the seasons. This evergreen forest gets over flooded during the rainy season. ... The forest goes under 20-30 feet water in the rainy season.

name: The Mountain Hiker
summary: Surfing, skating, parajumping, rock climbing and more, all in one tour

name: The Nature Seeker ||
summary: Visit the tea capital of Bangladesh and bless your eyes
description: Sreemangal is a hilly area covered with tea estates. There are 47 tea gardens inSreemangal. A large portion of world’s highest quality tea is grown here. It is also called the city of ‘two leaves and a bud. Sreemangal is famous for nature,forests and wildlife..

name: The Beach Suitor
summary: See the sunrise and sunset in the most attractive beach in Bangldesh
description: Kuakata, the daughter of the sea, the green land of unparalleled beauty; Located in Patuakhali district. Kuakata is the only beach in South Asia where you can stand and watch the sunrise and sunset. Undoubtedly, it is a great thing to observe the rising of the sun through the belly of the sea and the disappearance of the sun in the middle of the sea.

name: The Old State Viewer
summary: Visit the thriving trading hub of Bangladesh and witness the historc region of Bengal
description: Sonargaon is a tourist destination of Bangladesh. Located at about 37 km from Dhaka.It is the first place people think about for a day tour.People come to this place to visit the folk art museum,the abandoned city panam nagar and other interesting sights.The folk festival every year bring tourists from outside of the country every year.
